Sample Optimality and All-for-all Strategies in Personalized Federated and Collaborative Learning


Mathieu Even1, Laurent Massouli√©1,2 and Kevin Scaman1


1Inria - D√©partement d‚Äôinformatique de l‚ÄôENS

2MSR-Inria Joint Centre


Abstract.

In personalized Federated Learning, each member of a potentially large set of agents aims to train a model minimizing its loss function averaged over its local data distribution. We study this problem under the lens of stochastic optimization. Specifically, we introduce information-theoretic lower bounds on the number of samples required from all agents to approximately minimize the generalization error of a fixed agent. We then provide strategies matching these lower bounds, in the all-for-one and all-for-all settings where respectively one or all agents desire to minimize their own local function. Our strategies are based on a gradient filtering approach: provided prior knowledge on some notions of distances or discrepancies between local data distributions or functions, a given agent filters and aggregates stochastic gradients received from other agents, in order to achieve an optimal bias-variance trade-off.

1. Introduction

A central task in Federated Learning (McMahan et¬†al., 2017; Kairouz et¬†al., 2019) is the training of a common model from local data sets held by individual agents. A typical application is when users (e.g.¬†mobile phones, hospitals) want to make predictions (e.g.¬†next-word prediction, treatment prescriptions), but each has access to very few data samples, hence the need for collaboration. As highlighted by many recent works (e.g.¬†Hanzely et¬†al. (2020); Mansour et¬†al. (2020)), while training a global model yields better statistical efficiency on the combined datasets of all agents by increasing the number of samples linearly in the number of agents, this approach can suffer from a dramatically poor generalization error on local datasets. A solution to this generalization issue is the training of personalized models, a midway between a shared model between agents and models trained locally without any coordination.

An ideal approach would take the best of both worlds: increased statistical efficiency by using more samples, while keeping local generalization errors low. This raises the fundamental question: what is the optimal bias/variance tradeoff between personalization and coordination, and how can it be achieved?

We formulate the personalized federated learning problem as follows, studying it under the lens of stochastic optimization¬†(Bottou et¬†al., 2018). Consider N‚àà‚Ñï‚àóùëÅsuperscript‚ÑïN\in\mathbb{N}^{*} agents denoted by integers 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, each desiring to minimize its own local function fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, while sharing their stochastic gradients. Since only a limited number of samples are locally available, we focus on stochastic gradient descent-like algorithms, where agents each sequentially compute stochastic gradients giksuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëòg_{i}^{k} such that ùîº‚Äã[gik]=‚àáfiùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëò‚àásubscriptùëìùëñ\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}\right]=\nabla f_{i}. In order to reduce the sample complexity, i.e.¬†the number of samples or stochastic gradients required to reach small generalization error, agents thus need to use stochastic gradients from other agents, that are biased since in general ùîº‚Äã[gik]‚â†‚àáfjùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëò‚àásubscriptùëìùëó\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}\right]\neq\nabla f_{j}. We first consider the all-for-one objective, where a single agent iùëñi wants to minimize its local function (local generalization error), using its own information as well as information from agents j‚â†iùëóùëñj\neq i. We then address the all-for-all objective where all agents want to minimize their local function (local generalization error) in parallel using shared information. Our algorithms are based on a gradient filtering approach: in both all-for-one and all-for-all objectives, upon reception of stochastic gradients (gjk)jsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëóùëòùëó(g_{j}^{k})_{j}, agent iùëñi filters these gradients and aggregates them using some weights ŒªjsubscriptùúÜùëó\lambda_{j} into ‚àëjŒªj‚ÄãgjksubscriptùëósubscriptùúÜùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëóùëò\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}g_{j}^{k}, in order to achieve some bias/variance trade-off.

Contributions and outline of the paper

In this paper, we consider oracle models where at each step k=1,2,‚Ä¶ùëò12‚Ä¶k=1,2,\dots, one (or all) agent(s) may draw a sample according to its (their) local distribution. We aim at computing the number of stochastic gradients sampled from all agents, required to reach a small generalization error in both all-for-one and all-for-all formulations, in terms of: biases (distances between functions or distributions), regularity and noise assumptions. The oracle models, main assumptions and problem formulations are given in Section¬†2. Our main contributions are then as follows:

(i) In Section¬†3 we prove information theoretic lower bounds: to reach a target generalization error Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 for a fixed agent iùëñi, no algorithm can achieve a reduction in the number of oracle calls by a factor larger than the total number of agents ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon-close ‚Äìin a suitable sense‚Äì to agent iùëñi.

(ii) We next study a weighted gradient averaging algorithm for the all-for-one problem, matching this lower bound.

(iii) We then propose in Section¬†5 a parallel extension of the simple weighted gradient averaging algorithm that yields an efficient algorithm for the all-for-all problem. In this algorithm, agents compute stochastic gradients at their local estimate, and broadcast it to other agents who may use these to update their own estimates. For xk=(x1k,‚Ä¶,xNk)superscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëò‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëÅùëòx^{k}=(x_{1}^{k},\ldots,x_{N}^{k}) where xiksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòx_{i}^{k} is the local estimate of agent iùëñi at iteration kùëòk, updates of the all-for-all algorithm write as:

where gk=(g1k,‚Ä¶,gNk)superscriptùëîùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëî1ùëò‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëîùëÅùëòg^{k}=(g_{1}^{k},...,g_{N}^{k}) for an unbiased stochastic gradient¬†giksuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëòg_{i}^{k} of function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}, a step size Œ∑ùúÇ\eta, and a carefully chosen matrix¬†WùëäW. Agents iùëñi thus use stochastic gradients that are doubly biased, as gradients of a ‚Äúwrong function‚Äù fjsubscriptùëìùëóf_{j} instead of fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} computed at a ‚Äúwrong location‚Äù xjksubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëòùëóx^{k}_{j} instead of xiksubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëòùëñx^{k}_{i}.

Related works

Federated Learning is a paradigm in machine learning where training is done collaboratively among several agents, taking into account privacy constraints (McMahan et¬†al., 2017; Koneƒçn√Ω et¬†al., 2016; Kairouz et¬†al., 2019; Wang et¬†al., 2019). A central task is the training of a common model for all agents, for which both centralized approaches orchestrated by a server and decentralized approaches with no central coordinator (Nedich et¬†al., 2018) have been considered. The algorithms we propose in this paper are well suited for a decentralized implementation.

As observed in¬†Hanzely et¬†al. (2020), training a common model for all users can lead to poor generalization on certain tasks such as e.g. next-word prediction. To improve both accuracy and fairness, personalized models thus need to be learnt for each agent (Li et¬†al., 2020; Mohri et¬†al., 2019; Yu et¬†al., 2021). Approaches to personalization include fine-tuning (Cheng et¬†al., 2021; Khodak et¬†al., 2019), transfer learning techniques (Tripuraneni et¬†al., 2020; Wang et¬†al., 2019). Hanzely et¬†al. (2020); Fallah et¬†al. (2020) among others formulate personalization in FL as the training of local models with a regularization term that enforces collaboration between users. We refer the interested reader to Kulkarni et¬†al. (2020) for a broader survey of Personalized Federated Learning.

While the goal of personalization is to minimize local generalization errors, the above cited works do not provide theoretical guarantees over the sample complexity to obtain small local errors, but instead control errors on a regularized problem, in terms of communication rounds or full gradients used, and not in terms of samples used. Deng et¬†al. (2020); Mansour et¬†al. (2020) among others provide generalization errors under a statistical learning framework that depend on VC-dimensions and on distances between each local data distribution and the mixture of all datasets. Donahue and Kleinberg (2021a, b) study the bias-variance trade-off between collaboration and personalization for mean estimation in a game-theoretic framework. Chayti et¬†al. (2021); Grimberg et¬†al. (2021); Beaussart et¬†al. (2021) frame personalization as a stochastic optimization problem with biased gradients and are the works closest to ours. They consider the training of a single agent with biased gradients from another group of agents, i.e. the all-for-one problem and obtain performance guarantees in terms of distance between individual function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} and the average N‚àí1‚Äã‚àëjfjsuperscriptùëÅ1subscriptùëósubscriptùëìùëóN^{-1}\sum_{j}f_{j}. In contrast, we obtain more general performance bounds based on distance bounds between all pairs of functions fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}, fjsubscriptùëìùëóf_{j} (or equivalently, pairs of local distributions). In addition, we prove matching lower bounds. Finally, we also consider the all-for-all problem, for which we obtain efficient algorithms, and leverage in that setting the use of weaker bias assumptions than in the all-for-one problem.

2. Problem Statement and Assumptions

We now detail our objectives and the necessary technical assumptions. We consider general stochastic gradient methods and formulate our problems, assumptions and algorithms accordingly. Our lower bounds apply to a more specific problem, namely generalization error minimization, or GEM, where functions fjsubscriptùëìùëóf_{j} of all agents jùëój are all obtained from the same loss function ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell. These lower bounds a fortiori apply to the more general stochastic gradient setup of our algorithms.

Stochastic (sub)-gradients

Let fi:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùëñ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N be agent iùëñi‚Äôs local function to be minimized (e.g.¬†the average of a loss function over its local data distribution). At every iteration k=1,2,‚Ä¶ùëò12‚Ä¶k=1,2,\ldots, agent iùëñi may access unbiased i.i.d.¬†estimates gik‚Äã(x)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëòùë•g_{i}^{k}(x) of ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•\nabla f_{i}(x) (or of some subgradient s‚Äã(x)‚àà‚àÇfi‚Äã(x)ùë†ùë•subscriptùëìùëñùë•s(x)\in\partial f_{i}(x), depending on the regularity assumptions made):

We consider two different objectives. In the all-for-one setting, using information from all agents, a fixed agent iùëñi desires to minimize its own local function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} (typically, in collaborative GEM, fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} is the generalization error fi‚Äã(x)=ùîºùíüi‚Äã[‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæi)]subscriptùëìùëñùë•subscriptùîºsubscriptùíüùëñdelimited-[]‚Ñìùë•subscriptùúâùëñf_{i}(x)=\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}[\ell(x,\xi_{i})]). In the all-for-all setting, all agents want to minimize their own local function, using shared information.

Oracle models

To specify the information shared between agents via access to stochastic gradients, we define the following oracles. The synchronous oracle (resp.¬†asynchronous oracle) lets at every iteration all agents (resp.¬†only one agent) sample a stochastic gradient. After KùêæK queries from the synchronous oracle (resp.¬†asynchronous oracle), each agent will have sampled KùêæK (resp.¬†K/NùêæùëÅK/N on average) stochastic gradients for a total of N‚ÄãKùëÅùêæNK (resp.¬†KùêæK) in the whole set of agents. In the all-for-one setting where a fixed agent iùëñi desires to minimize its own local function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}, all agents jùëój can take the same xjk=xiksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòx_{j}^{k}=x_{i}^{k} as argument of their stochastic gradient, resulting in a simple stochastic gradient descent with biased gradients. The difficulty in analyzing all-for-all algorithms lies in the fact that stochastic gradients sampled by agent jùëój are doubly biased for agent iùëñi, being potentially computed at some xjksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùëòx_{j}^{k} distinct from xiksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòx_{i}^{k}.

Synchronous and asynchronous oracles At iterations k=1,2,‚Ä¶ùëò12‚Ä¶k=1,2,...: 1: A set of agents SksuperscriptùëÜùëòS^{k} is chosen: Sk={1,‚Ä¶,N}superscriptùëÜùëò1‚Ä¶ùëÅS^{k}={{\left\{1,\ldots,N\right\}}} for the synchronous oracle, Sk={ik}superscriptùëÜùëòsubscriptùëñùëòS^{k}={{\left\{i_{k}\right\}}} where iksubscriptùëñùëòi_{k} is sampled uniformly at random amongst agents, for the asynchronous oracle. ; 2: For all j‚ààSkùëósuperscriptùëÜùëòj\in S^{k}, agent jùëój chooses some yjksuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëóùëòy_{j}^{k} as a (possibly random) function of all previous stochastic gradients and iterates, and samples gjk‚Äã(yjk)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëóùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë¶ùëóùëòg_{j}^{k}(y_{j}^{k}); 3: All agents can then perform an update using these new stochastic gradients and all previous ones.

For fixed target precision Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0, the objective is to find, using TŒµsubscriptùëáùúÄT_{\varepsilon} samples from all agents in total, queried with synchronous or asynchronous oracles, models with local generalization error ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon. We prove matching lower and upper bounds on the sample complexity TŒµsubscriptùëáùúÄT_{\varepsilon} in the all-for-one and all-for-all settings.

Regularity, Bias and Noise Assumptions

Our regularity assumptions are standard111In fact our approach could be extended to other regularity assumptions, e.g. functions fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} with¬†Œº=0ùúá0\mu=0 as in Appendix¬†E.4, non-convex, or satisfying a Polyak-Lojasiewicz inequality; we do not pursue this here for lack of space. We also generalize (B.2) to function dissimilarities such as those in Karimireddy et¬†al. (2020), in Appendix¬†D, (B.3).; our bias (and gradient dissimilarity) assumptions are less classical, and can be derived from Wassertstein-like distribution-based distances in the GEM setting (Section¬†6 and Appendix¬†A). Assumption¬†(B.2) will be used in the all-for-one setting, while the less restrictive¬†(B.1) will be used in the all-for-all setting. It quantifies by how much agents‚Äô objectives differ. To the best of our knowledge it has not been previously used in Federated Learning. It is related to (B.2) through fi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚©Ω12‚ÄãŒº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚àí‚àáfi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚Äñ2=12‚ÄãŒº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚Äñ2subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ12ùúásuperscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜ‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ212ùúásuperscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜ2f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{2\mu}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right\|}}^{2}=\frac{1}{2\mu}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})\right\|}}^{2} under Œºùúá\mu-PL or strong convexity assumptions. More generally, we always have fi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚©Ω‚Äñxi‚ãÜ‚àíxj‚ãÜ‚Äñ‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚Äñsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜf_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant{{\left\|x_{i}^{\star}-x_{j}^{\star}\right\|}}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})\right\|}}. Our lower bounds apply to functions that verify both these bias assumptions, and a fortiori verify the assumptions made in our upper bounds where only one of these bias assumptions is required.

Finally, our upper bounds will use the following settings, that we refer to as Setting¬†1 and Setting¬†2:

  1. (1)

    Asynchronous oracle is used, assumption¬†(N.1) holds.

  2. (2)

    Synchronous oracle is used, assumption¬†(N.2) holds.

A key instance of our problem is collaborative generalization error minimization (GEM): let ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} for 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N be a probability distribution on a set ŒûŒû\Xi (agent iùëñi‚Äôs local distribution, not its empirical distribution), ‚Ñì:ùí≥√óŒû‚Üí‚Ñù:‚Ñì‚Üíùí≥Œû‚Ñù\ell:\mathcal{X}\times\Xi\to\mathbb{R} a loss function, and define the following local objective function, that agent iùëñi aims at minimizing:

fi‚Äã(x)=ùîºŒæi‚àºùíüi‚Äã[‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæi)],x‚ààùí≥.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùëñùë•subscriptùîºsimilar-tosubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùíüùëñdelimited-[]‚Ñìùë•subscriptùúâùëñùë•ùí≥f_{i}(x)=\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}\left[\ell(x,\xi_{i})\right]\,,\quad x\in\mathcal{X}\,. (5)

Function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} is thus the generalization error on agent iùëñi‚Äôs local distribution. Stochastic gradients are in that case of the form gik‚Äã(x)=‚àáx‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæik)superscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëòùë•subscript‚àáùë•‚Ñìùë•superscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëòg_{i}^{k}(x)=\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi_{i}^{k}) where Œæik‚àºùíüisimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëñùëòsubscriptùíüùëñ\xi_{i}^{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}. Counting the number of stochastic gradients used in the whole set of agents to reach a precision ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon for fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} thus reduces to computing the number of samples required from all agents to obtain local generalization error ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon for agent iùëñi. In Appendix¬†A we discuss how our bias assumptions follow from bounds on distances between distributions ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i}, ùíüjsubscriptùíüùëó\mathcal{D}_{j} together with practical scenarios where such bounds can be obtained.

Notation: in the rest of the paper, variables tùë°t or TùëáT denote the number of stochastic gradients giksuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñùëòg_{i}^{k} sampled (or data item sampled from personal distribution) from all agents, while variables kùëòk or KùêæK denote the iterates of the algorithms or equivalently to the number of oracle calls made.

The proof of these lower bounds (Appendix¬†B) builds on lower bounds based on Fano‚Äôs inequality (Duchi and Wainwright, 2013) for stochastic gradient descent¬†Agarwal et¬†al. (2012) or for information limited statistical estimation¬†(Zhang et¬†al., 2013; Duchi and Rogers, 2019), adapted to personalization.

Lower-bound interpretation. Theorem¬†1 states that, given the knowledge of (bi‚Äãj)subscriptùëèùëñùëó(b_{ij}) and B2superscriptùêµ2B^{2} (or¬†œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2}, Œºùúá\mu and LùêøL), there exist difficult instances of the problem that satisfy assumption¬†(N.1) (or¬†(N.2)) and both bias assumptions¬†(B.1) and¬†(B.2) for bùëèb, such that the number of samples from all agents (generated through the synchronous or asynchronous oracle) needed to obtain a generalization error of ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon for an agent iùëñi is lower-bounded by the right hand sides of the equations in Theorem¬†1.

Collaboration speedup. The factor N√óC‚ÄãB2‚Äãr2‚ÄãŒµ‚àí2ùëÅùê∂superscriptùêµ2superscriptùëü2superscriptùúÄ2N\times CB^{2}r^{2}\varepsilon^{-2} is reminiscent of stochastic gradient descent, and is present in¬†Agarwal et¬†al. (2012): without cooperation, this is the sample complexity of SGD for a fixed agent (for TùëáT samples from all agents, only T/NùëáùëÅT/N are taken from a given agent iùëñi). Cooperation appears in the factor 1/ùí©iŒµ‚Äã(b/4)1superscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄùëè41/\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(b/4): the sample complexity is inversely proportional to the number of agents jùëój that have functions (or distributions) similar to that of iùëñi. One cannot hope for better than a linear speedup proportional to agents Œµ/4ùúÄ4\varepsilon/4-close to iùëñi, in the sense that the functions parameterized by the loss function and distributions verify fi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚©Ωbi‚Äãj/4subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsubscriptùëèùëñùëó4f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij}/4 and ‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2‚©Ωb~i‚Äãjsuperscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëóùë•2subscript~ùëèùëñùëó{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant\tilde{b}_{ij} for all x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where b~=(b/r)2~ùëèsuperscriptùëèùëü2\tilde{b}=(b/r)^{2} in the first case, and b~=b/r2=Œº‚Äãb~ùëèùëèsuperscriptùëü2ùúáùëè\tilde{b}=b/r^{2}=\mu b in the second.

Bias assumptions and collaborative GEM. In Section¬†6, we relate ‚Äñ‚àáfi‚àí‚àáfj‚Äñnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñ‚àásubscriptùëìùëó{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}-\nabla f_{j}\right\|}} to distribution-based distances d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)subscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëód_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j}) in the GEM setting, where d‚Ñãsubscriptùëë‚Ñãd_{\mathcal{H}} is a 1-Wassertstein-like distance. We prove that the distributions leading to the functions used to prove Theorem¬†1 verify d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)‚©Ωbi‚Äãjsubscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëósubscriptùëèùëñùëód_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant b_{ij}; thus, the distribution based distances also sharply characterize the sample complexity. The requirement for the lower bound to apply that (bi‚Äãj)subscriptùëèùëñùëó(b_{ij}) verifies the triangle inequality is thus quite natural, when translating bias assumptions into distribution-based distances.

4. Weighted Gradient Averaging is optimal in the All-for-one setting

We now prove that a weighted gradient averaging (WGA) algorithm is optimal in the all-for-one setting. Fix the agent¬†iùëñi who desires to minimize its local function fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} (no longer assumed to derive from a loss function). The iterates of the weighted gradient averaging algorithm write as, for both synchronous and asynchronous oracles:

xk+1=xk‚àíŒ∑‚Äã‚àëj=1NŒªj‚ÄãGk‚Äã(x)j,superscriptùë•ùëò1superscriptùë•ùëòùúÇsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëósuperscriptùê∫ùëòsubscriptùë•ùëóx^{k+1}=x^{k}-\eta\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}G^{k}(x)_{j}\,, (6)

for some step size Œ∑>0ùúÇ0\eta>0 and stochastic vector Œª‚àà‚ÑùNùúÜsuperscript‚ÑùùëÅ\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, and:

In the WGA algorithm, all agents involved keep the same local estimates xiksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòx_{i}^{k}. Theorem¬†4 presents a tuning of the algorithm for a fixed target precision ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon; using a doubling trick as we do in Appendix¬†E.3 yields time-adaptive algorithms, that achieve the same sample complexity (up to constant factors) for any Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0.

In the GEM setting, the proposed WGA algorithm consists in training a model over the distribution ùíüiŒµsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùúÄ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\varepsilon}, a mixture of the distributions {ùíüj:d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)‚©ΩŒµ/2}conditional-setsubscriptùíüùëósubscriptùëë‚ÑãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëóùúÄ2{{\left\{\mathcal{D}_{j}\,:\,d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\varepsilon/2\right\}}}, where d‚Ñãsubscriptùëë‚Ñãd_{\mathcal{H}} is a distribution-based distance, leading to an increase in the number of samples available by a factor ùí©iŒµsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon} (thus reducing the variance), while keeping the bias of order ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon.

5. All-for-all Strategies

We now focus on the more challenging all-for-all setting: all agents desire to minimize their local function. We first present a naive approach, that proves to be sample-optimal, but that cannot be used in practice for large scale problems, as it requires a number computations per oracle call for each agent that increases with NùëÅN. We thus introduce and analyze the all-for-all algorithm, the main algorithmic contribution of our paper.

Naive Approach

Each agent iùëñi keeps NùëÅN shared local models x1k,‚Ä¶,xNksuperscriptsubscriptùë•1ùëò‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëÅùëòx_{1}^{k},\ldots,x_{N}^{k}, where xjksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùëòx_{j}^{k} estimates xj‚ãÜsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜx_{j}^{\star} at iteration kùëòk (the knowledge of xjksuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëóùëòx_{j}^{k} needs to be shared by all agents). At each iteration kùëòk, when a sample Œæjksubscriptsuperscriptùúâùëòùëó\xi^{k}_{j} is obtained at agent jùëój, it is used by that agent to compute unbiased estimates of ‚àáfj‚Äã(xik)‚àásubscriptùëìùëósubscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëòùëñ\nabla f_{j}(x^{k}_{i}) for all i‚àà[N]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëÅi\in[N]. These are then broadcast to all agents iùëñi that verify bi‚Äãj‚©ΩŒµsubscriptùëèùëñùëóùúÄb_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon (target precision). Agents then perform NùëÅN weighted gradient averaging algorithms simultaneously, leading to the following guarantees. Under the assumptions of Theorem¬†2.1, we have max1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[fi‚Äã(xik)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)]‚©ΩŒµsubscript1ùëñùëÅùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜùúÄ\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon, with a number of data items sampled from personal distribution TŒµsubscriptùëáùúÄT_{\varepsilon} of:

TŒµ‚©Ω4‚ÄãD2‚ÄãB2Œµ2‚Äãmax1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN‚Å°Nùí©iŒµ‚Äã(2‚Äãb).subscriptùëáùúÄ4superscriptùê∑2superscriptùêµ2superscriptùúÄ2subscript1ùëñùëÅùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ2ùëèT_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{4D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\,.

Under the assumptions of Theorem¬†2.2, we have max1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[fi‚Äã(xik)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)]‚©ΩŒµsubscript1ùëñùëÅùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜùúÄ\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon, with a number of data item sampled from personal distribution TŒµsubscriptùëáùúÄT_{\varepsilon} of:

TŒµ‚©Ωùí™~‚Äã(Œ∫‚ÄãœÉ2Œº‚ÄãŒµ‚Äãmax1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN‚Å°Nùí©iŒµ‚Äã(2‚Äãb)).subscriptùëáùúÄ~ùí™ùúÖsuperscriptùúé2ùúáùúÄsubscript1ùëñùëÅùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ2ùëèT_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\kappa\sigma^{2}}{\mu\varepsilon}\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\right)\,.

Using the all-for-one lower bounds of Theorem¬†1, this proves to be optimal. Yet, the memory requirements and computation/communication costs of this approach are forbiddingly high for large NùëÅN (they scale with ùí©iŒµsuperscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon} for agent iùëñi), hence the all-for-all algorithm below, that relaxes the metric considered by controlling the averaged local errors N‚àí1‚Äã‚àë1‚©Ωi‚©ΩNùîº‚Äã[fi‚Äã(xik)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)]superscriptùëÅ1subscript1ùëñùëÅùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜN^{-1}\sum_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right] instead of worst-case ones max1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[fi‚Äã(xik)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)]subscript1ùëñùëÅùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]. Furthermore, relaxing the quantity controlled leads to weaker necessary bias assumptions.

The All-for-all algorithm

We now present the all-for-all algorithm (AFA), an adaptation of the weighted gradient averaging algorithm to the all-for-all setting, where all agents desire to use all stochastic gradients computed. For 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, initialize xi0=x0‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ0subscriptùë•0superscript‚Ñùùëëx_{i}^{0}=x_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Collaborative speedup. In Setting¬†1, denoting TŒµ‚Äã(i)subscriptùëáùúÄùëñT_{\varepsilon}(i) the sample complexity in the all-for-one setting (that matched the corresponding lower bound), we observe that in the all-for-all regime, we obtain TŒµ‚©Ω1N‚Äã‚àëiTŒµ‚Äã(i)subscriptùëáùúÄ1ùëÅsubscriptùëñsubscriptùëáùúÄùëñT_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}T_{\varepsilon}(i). The speedup in comparison with a no-collaboration strategy (all agents locally performing SGD) is 1N‚Äã‚àëi1ùí©iŒµ‚Äã(2‚Äãb)1ùëÅsubscriptùëñ1superscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ2ùëè\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}: the mean of all all-for-one speed-ups. Similarly in Setting¬†2, the speed-up in comparison with the no-collaboration setting is still 1N‚Äã‚àëi1ùí©iŒµ‚Äã(2‚Äãb)1ùëÅsubscriptùëñ1superscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ2ùëè\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)} in the statistical regime. In Setting¬†2, one could obtain Œ∫ùúÖ\sqrt{\kappa} instead of Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa in the optimization term, using accelerated gradient methods (with additive noise here), leading to a faster convergence to the statistical regime (first term of the max in Theorem¬†4.2), where we have the collaboration speedup. We present in Appendix¬†E.3 a time-adaptive variant with varying step sizes and matrices, that share the same sample complexity, and Theorem¬†8 in Appendix¬†E.4 is the case Œº=0ùúá0\mu=0.

Assumption¬†(B.1). Importantly, controlling the mean of local generalization errors leads to a much weaker bias assumption: instead of requiring a uniform control of gradient norms (as is done in all previous works, and in our all-for-one setting), our all-for-all algorithm only requires that for some (bi‚Äãj)subscriptùëèùëñùëó(b_{ij}), we have fi‚Äã(xj‚ãÜ)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚©Ωbi‚Äãjsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëó‚ãÜsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜsubscriptùëèùëñùëóf_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij}: in the GEM setting e.g., even when gradients of fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} and fjsubscriptùëìùëóf_{j} may differ a lot, if agent jùëój‚Äôs optimal model generalizes well-enough under agent iùëñi‚Äôs distribution, they should collaborate. We believe this notion of function proximity that we leverage in this setting to be the weakest possible.

Intuition behind the algorithm. Perhaps surprisingly, matrix WùëäW is in general not a gossip matrix (i.e.¬†such that W‚Äãùüô=ùüôùëä11W\mathds{1}=\mathds{1}): agent iùëñi does not aggregate a convex combination of stochastic gradients, but a combination with scalars that do not necessarily sum to 1. In the collaborative GEM setting, we thus cannot say that the all-for-all algorithm acts as if, in parallel, each agent iùëñi trains a model on the mixture of distributions ùíüjsubscriptùíüùëó\mathcal{D}_{j} with weights Wi‚ÄãjsubscriptùëäùëñùëóW_{ij}. In fact, as the analysis shows below, agent iùëñi trains a model on the mixture of distributions, with weights Œªi‚ÄãjsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó\lambda_{ij}, if ŒõŒõ\Lambda is a stochastic square root of matrix WùëäW (Œõ‚ÄãŒõ‚ä§=WŒõsuperscriptŒõtopùëä\Lambda\Lambda^{\top}=W). Thus, the all-for-all algorithm is exactly a paralleled version of weighted gradient averagings, where agent iùëñi uses the stochastic vector (Œªi‚Äãj)1‚©Ωj‚©ΩNsubscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó1ùëóùëÅ(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}. In order to account for inter-dependencies between agents that do not directly share information, the all-for-all gradient filtering uses weights Wi‚ÄãjsubscriptùëäùëñùëóW_{ij} to aggregate information, instead of Œªi‚ÄãjsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó\lambda_{ij}. Propagating information using a matrix WùëäW, that induces a similarity graph GWsubscriptùê∫ùëäG_{W} on {1,‚Ä¶,N}1‚Ä¶ùëÅ{{\left\{1,\ldots,N\right\}}}, such that (i‚Äãj)‚ààEWùëñùëósubscriptùê∏ùëä(ij)\in E_{W} if Wi‚Äãj>0subscriptùëäùëñùëó0W_{ij}>0, is quite natural¬†(Vanhaesebrouck et¬†al., 2017; Bellet et¬†al., 2018); yet, ours is the first analysis to give such precise generalization error bounds, through the use of a stochastic optimization framework.

Degrees of freedom offered by WùëäW. In comparison to Theorem¬†3, the classical personalized FL approaches that consider personalized local models of the form xi=x¬Ø‚àíŒ¥isubscriptùë•ùëñ¬Øùë•subscriptùõøùëñx_{i}=\bar{x}-\delta_{i}, where x¬Ø¬Øùë•\bar{x} is some global quantity shared by all agents, perturbed (and personalized) by some local quantity Œ¥isubscriptùõøùëñ\delta_{i} (e.g.¬†averaging between local and a global models), can be seen as the special instances where, for all iùëñi, we have Œªi‚Äãi=1‚àíŒ±isubscriptùúÜùëñùëñ1subscriptùõºùëñ\lambda_{ii}=1-\alpha_{i} and Œªi‚Äãj=Œ±iN‚àí1subscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscriptùõºùëñùëÅ1\lambda_{ij}=\frac{\alpha_{i}}{N-1} if i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j for some Œ±isubscriptùõºùëñ\alpha_{i}, and leads to bias terms of the form 1N‚Äã‚àëiŒ±iN‚àí1‚Äã‚àëj‚â†ibi‚Äãj1ùëÅsubscriptùëñsubscriptùõºùëñùëÅ1subscriptùëóùëñsubscriptùëèùëñùëó\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{\alpha_{i}}{N-1}\sum_{j\neq i}b_{ij}. Full and naive collaboration (a single model trained for all users) corresponds to Œªi‚Äãj=1/NsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó1ùëÅ\lambda_{ij}=1/N for all i,jùëñùëói,j, and leads to a bias term of 1N2‚Äã‚àëi,jbi‚Äãj1superscriptùëÅ2subscriptùëñùëósubscriptùëèùëñùëó\frac{1}{N^{2}}\sum_{i,j}b_{ij}. The degrees of freedom offered by our matrix WùëäW (and by coefficients Œªi‚ÄãjsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó\lambda_{ij}) enable pairwise agent adaptation, and tighter generalization guarantees and bias/variance tradeoffs.

Proof sketch of convergence guarantees.

Since brutally analyzing convergence of the iterates (xk)superscriptùë•ùëò(x^{k}) generated with xk+1=xk‚àíW‚ÄãGksuperscriptùë•ùëò1superscriptùë•ùëòùëäsuperscriptùê∫ùëòx^{k+1}=x^{k}-WG^{k} seems impossible due to both gradient biases and model biases between agents, we study these iterates through the introduction of a different but related problem. This approach is in fact similar to some decentralized optimization ones, where a dual problem or a related energy function is often introduced (Scaman et¬†al., 2019; Even et¬†al., 2021), upon which well-studied algorithms are applied. The related problem we formulate is different from and more flexible than all the different personalized FL problems in the literature (Hanzely et¬†al., 2020; T.¬†Dinh et¬†al., 2020), that consider regularization terms that enforce consensus. For Œª=(Œªi‚Äãj)1‚©Ωi,j‚©ΩNùúÜsubscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùëóformulae-sequence1ùëñùëóùëÅ\lambda=(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N} a stochastic matrix (such that for all 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, we have ‚àëj=1NŒªi‚Äãj=1superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó1\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}=1), let fŒõsuperscriptùëìŒõf^{\Lambda} be defined as:

6. Collaborative GEM

In this section, we place ourselves in the GEM setting (loss function ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell, distributions (ùíüi)isubscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùëñ(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i}). We briefly elaborate (see Appendix¬†A for further details) on the collaborative GEM setting we used through the paper, clearly define the distribution-based distances related to bias assumptions¬†(B.1) and¬†(B.3), and introduce toy problems under which the bias upperbounds may be known.

6.1. Distribution-based distances.

For ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} a set of functions from ŒûŒû\Xi to ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d} and ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤ùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime} two probability distributions on ŒûŒû\Xi, we define:

d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤)=suph‚àà‚Ñã‚Äñùîº‚Äã[h‚Äã(Œæ)‚àíh‚Äã(Œæ‚Ä≤)]‚Äñ,subscriptùëë‚Ñãùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤subscriptsupremum‚Ñé‚Ñãnormùîºdelimited-[]‚Ñéùúâ‚Ñésuperscriptùúâ‚Ä≤d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[h(\xi)-h(\xi^{\prime})\right]\right\|}}\,,

where Œæ‚àºùíüsimilar-toùúâùíü\xi\sim\mathcal{D} and Œæ‚Ä≤‚àºùíü‚Ä≤similar-tosuperscriptùúâ‚Ä≤superscriptùíü‚Ä≤\xi^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}. d‚Ñãsubscriptùëë‚Ñãd_{\mathcal{H}} is a pseudo-distance on the set of probability measures on ŒûŒû\Xi. 6.2. Weakly supervised setting.

In a scenario where, from a large pool of unlabelled data (distributions (ùíü^i)isubscriptsubscript^ùíüùëñùëñ(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{i})_{i}), requiring a label led to a sample from ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} but were costly, agents would benefit from computing distance-based distributions between unlabelled distributions (ùíü^i)isubscriptsubscript^ùíüùëñùëñ(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{i})_{i} (possible thanks to a large amount of unlabelled samples); these computed distances would then help to reduce the number of labelled samples required.

6.4. Illustration of our theory.

To test the robustness of our algorithms and our theory, we use in our experiments the mean estimation problem used in the strongly convex and smooth lower bound of Theorem¬†1: ‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)=12‚Äã‚Äñx‚àíŒæ‚Äñ2‚Ñìùë•ùúâ12superscriptnormùë•ùúâ2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|x-\xi\right\|}}^{2}, x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for Œæùúâ\xi a dùëëd-dimensional Bernoulli random variable. We use the time-adaptive version of Algorithm¬†1, and we place ourselves in the setting of Section¬†A.4, where agent distributions are drawn from a distribution of distributions: for N=100ùëÅ100N=100 agents, we draw (pi)1‚©Ωi‚©ΩNsubscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëñùëÅ(p_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N} i.i.d.¬†uniformly distributed in [0,1]01[0,1], and pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} is the parameter of agent iùëñi‚Äôs Bernoulli variables. We draw 103superscript10310^{3} samples for each agent, and we compute for 1‚©Ωt‚©ΩT1ùë°ùëá1\leqslant t\leqslant T the averaged local generalization errors (here the error from the mean), namely 1N‚Äã‚àëi=1N12‚Äã‚Äñxit‚àípi‚Äñ21ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅ12superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°subscriptùëùùëñ2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|x_{i}^{t}-p_{i}\right\|}}^{2}, where xitsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùë°x_{i}^{t} is the output of the algorithm after tùë°t samples drawn. As expected and as illustrated in Figure¬†1(a), our all-for-all approach benefits from both no-collaboration (each agent locally estimating its mean pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} with only its locally available samples, in orange in the graph) and single-model approaches (a fully centralized minimization of 1N‚Äã‚àëifi‚Äã(x)1ùëÅsubscriptùëñsubscriptùëìùëñùë•\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f_{i}(x), in green in the graph), through both a convergence to the true mean, and a non-asymptotic acceleration. In Figure¬†1(b), we study the effect of noise on the estimation of bias parameters bi‚Äãjsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{ij} (that here correspond to bi‚Äãj=12‚Äã(pi‚àípj)2subscriptùëèùëñùëó12superscriptsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëó2b_{ij}=\frac{1}{2}(p_{i}-p_{j})^{2}), by taking as inputs in algorithms bi‚Äãjnoisy=12‚Äã(pi+ni‚àípj‚àínj)2superscriptsubscriptùëèùëñùëónoisy12superscriptsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëõùëñsubscriptùëùùëósubscriptùëõùëó2b_{ij}^{\rm noisy}=\frac{1}{2}(p_{i}+n_{i}-p_{j}-n_{j})^{2}, where nisubscriptùëõùëñn_{i} are i.i.d.¬†uniformly distributed in [‚àínoise,noise]noisenoise[-{\rm noise},{\rm noise}], for different noise values (Figure¬†1(b)). All-for-all algorithm appears to be quite robust to noise: for small noise amplitudes (0.02 and 0.08, and even 0.18), performances are not too degraded. For (abusively) large noise values (0.32 and 0.5), the non-asymptotic speedup is kept, with degraded asymptotic performances. Still, in the range of parameters considered, these perform better than no-collaboration and single model approaches.

Discussion and conclusion.

In this paper, we quantified in term of function biases (bi‚Äãjsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{ij}), stochastic gradient noise or amplitudes (œÉ2superscriptùúé2\sigma^{2} or B2superscriptùêµ2B^{2}), target precision Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 and functions regularity parameters, the benefit of collaboration between agents for shared minimization using stochastic gradient algorithms. Our lower bound (Theorem¬†1) states that in the¬†all-for-one setting, assumption parameters being fixed, no algorithm matches the performances of weighted gradient averagings in terms of sample optimality. Another lower bound (and corresponding upper-bounds) that would be worth investigating is: without any knowledge on biases bi‚Äãjsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{ij}, what is the worst case complexity of an algorithm that would thus need to learn who to learn with? We extended weighted gradient averagings to the all-for-all setting, technically more challenging, through the introduction of a related problem, simplifying the analysis of such algorithms.

The main limitation of our work lies in the assumption that upper-bounds on the biases bi‚Äãjsubscriptùëèùëñùëób_{ij} are known. We investigate in Section¬†A scenarii in which this assumption is valid. Yet, as mentionned above, learning who to learn with and how is a challenging question worth tackling. Extending our work to model agnosticism together with data heterogeneity would require bias assumptions such as our distribution-based ones in Section¬†A. Finally, fairness issues might be raised by our approaches in the all-for-all setting: we consider the average errors amongst agents and therefore do not ensure bounds on the supremum of all local errors. Still, incentives to collaborate and send gradients to other users are the hope of being helped back (matrix WùëäW is symmetric in Algorithm¬†1).

Appendix A The Case of Collaborative Generalization Error Minimization (GEM)

In most of the related works and in this paper, the quantities equivalent to our bias assumptions are assumed to be known by the optimizer. Yet, while this assumption makes analyses possible, the knowledge of these quantities is a strong assumption. In this section, we provide settings and toy problems under which these assumptions are natural. We first begin by introducing distribution based distances between agents, in order to control gradient biases in the setting where functions are of the form¬†(5) for a shared loss ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell and local distributions (ùíüi)isubscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùëñ(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i}, for collaborative GEM. We then present two settings for this problem.

A.1. Distribution-based distances

In order to quantify the bias/variance tradeoff that appears when using stochastic gradients computed by other agents, we define the following notion of distance.

Definition 1.

For ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H} a set of functions from ŒûŒû\Xi to ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d} and ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤ùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime} two probability distributions on ŒûŒû\Xi, we define:

d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤)=suph‚àà‚Ñã‚Äñùîº‚Äã[h‚Äã(Œæ)‚àíh‚Äã(Œæ‚Ä≤)]‚Äñ,subscriptùëë‚Ñãùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤subscriptsupremum‚Ñé‚Ñãnormùîºdelimited-[]‚Ñéùúâ‚Ñésuperscriptùúâ‚Ä≤d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[h(\xi)-h(\xi^{\prime})\right]\right\|}}\,,

Some instances of these distances encompass:

  1. (1)

    For ‚Ñã=‚ÑãAffine‚Ñãsubscript‚ÑãAffine\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine} the set of 1-Lipschitz affine functions, we have d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíü,ùíü‚Ä≤)=‚Äñùîº‚Äã[Œæ]‚àíùîº‚Äã[Œæ‚Ä≤]‚Äñsubscriptùëë‚Ñãùíüsuperscriptùíü‚Ä≤normùîºdelimited-[]ùúâùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùúâ‚Ä≤d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})={{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\xi\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\xi^{\prime}\right]\right\|}}.

    For ‚Ñã=‚ÑãLoc.Bounded‚Ñãsubscript‚Ñãformulae-sequenceLocBounded\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{\rm Loc.Bounded} defined as {h:Œû‚Üí‚Ñùds.t.‚àÄŒæ‚ààŒû,Diam‚Äã(h‚Äã(‚Ñ¨‚Äã(Œæ,1)‚à©Œû))‚©Ω1}conditional-set‚Ñéformulae-sequence‚ÜíŒûsuperscript‚Ñùùëës.t.formulae-sequencefor-allùúâŒûDiam‚Ñé‚Ñ¨ùúâ1Œû1{{\left\{h:\Xi\to\mathbb{R}^{d}\quad\text{s.t.}\quad\forall\xi\in\Xi,\,{\rm Diam}\big{(}h(\mathcal{B}(\xi,1)\cap\Xi)\big{)}\leqslant 1\right\}}}, we also obtain the total variation distance.

The definition of d‚Ñãsubscriptùëë‚Ñãd_{\mathcal{H}} is motivated by the fact that, for fixed x‚ààùí≥ùë•ùí≥x\in\mathcal{X} and 1‚©Ωi,j‚©ΩNformulae-sequence1ùëñùëóùëÅ1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, we have:

‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáfj‚Äã(x)‚Äñnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•‚àásubscriptùëìùëóùë•\displaystyle{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}} =‚Äñùîº‚Äã[‚àáx‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæi)‚àí‚àáx‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæj)]‚Äñabsentnormùîºdelimited-[]subscript‚àáùë•‚Ñìùë•subscriptùúâùëñsubscript‚àáùë•‚Ñìùë•subscriptùúâùëó\displaystyle={{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi_{i})-\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi_{j})\right]\right\|}}
‚©Ωd‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj).absentsubscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëó\displaystyle\leqslant d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\,.

if (Œæ‚ààŒû‚Ü¶‚àáx‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ))‚àà‚ÑãùúâŒûmaps-tosubscript‚àáùë•‚Ñìùë•ùúâ‚Ñã\big{(}\xi\in\Xi\mapsto\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi)\big{)}\in\mathcal{H} where (Œæi,Œæj)‚àºùíüi√óùíüjsimilar-tosubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùúâùëósubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëó(\xi_{i},\xi_{j})\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}\times\mathcal{D}_{j}.

We thus add a fourth bias assumptions to our list in Section¬†2, called distribution-based bias assumption: for some function set ‚Ñã‚Ñã\mathcal{H}, for all 1‚©Ωi,j‚©ΩNformulae-sequence1ùëñùëóùëÅ1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, for all x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)‚©Ωb^i‚Äãjsubscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëósubscript^ùëèùëñùëód_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\hat{b}_{ij} for some non negative weights b^^ùëè\hat{b}, and for all x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, (Œæ‚ààŒû‚Ü¶‚àáx‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ))‚àà‚ÑãùúâŒûmaps-tosubscript‚àáùë•‚Ñìùë•ùúâ‚Ñã\big{(}\xi\in\Xi\mapsto\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi)\big{)}\in\mathcal{H}. This assumptions is verified in the following settings for mean estimation and regression.

  1. (1)

    For ‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)=12‚Äã(x‚àíŒæ)2‚Ñìùë•ùúâ12superscriptùë•ùúâ2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}(x-\xi)^{2} (mean estimation), distribution-based bias assumption holds for ‚ÑãAffinesubscript‚ÑãAffine\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine}, and the distance to consider is thus ‚Äñùîº‚Äã[Œæi]‚àíùîº‚Äã[Œæj]‚Äñnormùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùúâùëñùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùúâùëó{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{i}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{j}\right]\right\|}}.

  2. (2)

    For quadratic loss (linear regression) ‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)=12‚Äã(a‚ä§‚Äãx‚àíb)2‚Ñìùë•ùúâ12superscriptsuperscriptùëétopùë•ùëè2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}(a^{\top}x-b)^{2} where Œæ=(a‚Äãa‚ä§,b‚Äãa‚ä§)ùúâùëésuperscriptùëétopùëèsuperscriptùëétop\xi=(aa^{\top},ba^{\top}), we have ‚Ñã=D‚Äã‚ÑãAffine‚Ñãùê∑subscript‚ÑãAffine\mathcal{H}=D\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine}, where Dùê∑D is the diameter of the space in which are iterates lie, and the distance to consider is thus a scaled 1-Wassertein distance between distributions

  3. (3)

    For logisic regression ‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)=log‚Å°(1+e‚àíb‚Äãa‚ä§‚Äãx)‚Ñìùë•ùúâ1superscriptùëíùëèsuperscriptùëétopùë•\ell(x,\xi)=\log(1+e^{-ba^{\top}x}) where Œæ=b‚Äãa‚ä§ùúâùëèsuperscriptùëétop\xi=ba^{\top}, we have ‚Ñã=(1+1e)‚Äã‚ÑãLipschitz‚Ñã11ùëísubscript‚ÑãLipschitz\mathcal{H}=(1+\frac{1}{e})\mathcal{H}_{\rm Lipschitz} and the distance to consider is thus the 1-Wassertein distance between distributions (scaled with a constant factor).

  4. (4)

    For the hinge loss ‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)=max‚Å°(0,1‚àíb‚Äãa‚ä§‚Äãx)‚Ñìùë•ùúâ01ùëèsuperscriptùëétopùë•\ell(x,\xi)=\max(0,1-ba^{\top}x), for Œæ=b‚Äãa‚ä§ùúâùëèsuperscriptùëétop\xi=ba^{\top} we have ‚Ñã=D‚Äã‚ÑãBounded‚Ñãùê∑subscript‚ÑãBounded\mathcal{H}=D\mathcal{H}_{\rm Bounded} where Dùê∑D is the diameter of the space in which are iterates lie, and the distance to consider between distributions is thus a scaled total variation distance.

Thus, instead of controlling uniform concentration bounds on the gradients (under the GEM assumption, this can be done using anisotropic uniform concentration bounds, e.g.¬†Even and Massoulie [2021]), one can leverage our bias assumptions by controlling distribution-based distances.

Proposition 1.

If for all 1‚©Ωi,j‚©ΩNformulae-sequence1ùëñùëóùëÅ1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)‚©Ωb^i‚Äãjsubscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëósubscript^ùëèùëñùëód_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\hat{b}_{ij} (i.e.¬†distribution-based bias assumption holds), then:

  1. (1)

    Bias assumption¬†(B.1) holds for bi‚Äãj=D‚ãÜ‚Äãb^i‚Äãjsubscriptùëèùëñùëósuperscriptùê∑‚ãÜsubscript^ùëèùëñùëób_{ij}=D^{\star}\hat{b}_{ij};

  2. (2)

    Bias assumption¬†(B.2) holds for b~i‚Äãj=b^i‚Äãj2subscript~ùëèùëñùëósuperscriptsubscript^ùëèùëñùëó2\tilde{b}_{ij}=\hat{b}_{ij}^{2}.

A.2. Lower-bounds (Theorem¬†1) in term of distribution based distances

Theorem¬†1 being formulated as IT-lower bounds for collaborative GEM, the distribution-based distances we introduced perfectly adapt to it. In fact, in the proof of the lower bounds, the distributions we build verify d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)‚©Ωbi‚Äãjsubscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëósubscriptùëèùëñùëód_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant b_{ij} if ‚Ñã‚äÇ‚ÑãL‚Äão‚Äãc.B‚Äão‚Äãu‚Äãn‚Äãd‚Äãe‚Äãd‚Ñãsubscript‚Ñãformulae-sequenceùêøùëúùëêùêµùëúùë¢ùëõùëëùëíùëë\mathcal{H}\subset\mathcal{H}_{Loc.Bounded}, so that the following directly holds.

A.3. Weak supervision

We explicit in this section another paradigm in which the knowledge of some distribution-based bias assumptions is realistic, in a weakly supervised learning setting. More precisely, assume that the desired task is a classification or regression one: random variables Œæùúâ\xi are of the form Œæ=(Œ∂,Œ≤)ùúâùúÅùõΩ\xi=(\zeta,\beta) for some Œ∂‚ààZ‚äÇ‚ÑùD1ùúÅùëçsuperscript‚Ñùsubscriptùê∑1\zeta\in Z\subset\mathbb{R}^{D_{1}} and some label Œ≤‚àà‚ÑùD2ùõΩsuperscript‚Ñùsubscriptùê∑2\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{D_{2}}. For every agent 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, let ùíüiŒ∂superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùúÅ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta} be the Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta-marginal of ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i}. In our weakly supervised learning setting, we assume that there exists some (eventually random) function ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} that maps unlabelled data Œ∂ùúÅ\zeta to their labelled ones i.e.¬†for some ‚Ñí:Z‚ÜíŒû:‚Ñí‚ÜíùëçŒû\mathcal{L}:Z\to\Xi, the random variable ‚Ñí‚Äã(Œ∂i)‚ÑísubscriptùúÅùëñ\mathcal{L}(\zeta_{i}) is of same law as Œæi‚àºùíüisimilar-tosubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùíüùëñ\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i} for Œ∂i‚àºùíüiŒ∂similar-tosubscriptùúÅùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùúÅ\zeta_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta}. While many samples may be accessible and drawn from ùíüiŒ∂superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùúÅ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta} for every agent 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, labelling data i.e.¬†applying function ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} in order to recover samples of law ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} is assumed to be costly. For instance, applying ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} in medical data analysis could require the help form an expert (a radiologist, ‚Ä¶).

Agents would benefit from computing distances between distributions ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} using marginals ùíüiŒ∂superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùúÅ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta}: under mild assumptions on the function ‚Ñí‚Ñí\mathcal{L} (Lipschitzness with high probability, mainly), distances d‚Ñã‚Äã(ùíüi,ùíüj)subscriptùëë‚Ñãsubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüùëód_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j}) are upperbounded by distances between ùíüiŒ∂superscriptsubscriptùíüùëñùúÅ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta} and ùíüjŒ∂superscriptsubscriptùíüùëóùúÅ\mathcal{D}_{j}^{\zeta}. Thus, in this setting, agents would benefit from collaborating: computing distribution-based distances would not require expert advices, while reducing the total number of expert calls required by reducing the number of samples needed to be drawn from each ùíüisubscriptùíüùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i} through collaboration.

A.4. Infinitely-Many-Agents Limit and Geometrical Prior Knowledge

We introduce the infinitely-many-agents limit, by taking N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty with added structure on the problem below. This toy-problem illustrates a geometric structure under which the knowledge of distribution-based bias assumptions is realistic. Let ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P} be a set of probability laws and Œò‚äÇ‚ÑùpŒòsuperscript‚Ñùùëù\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{p} be a set parameterizing ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P} in the sense that ùí´ùí´\mathcal{P} can be written as {ùíüŒ∏,Œ∏‚ààŒò}subscriptùíüùúÉùúÉŒò\{\mathcal{D}_{\theta},\,\theta\in\Theta\} where ùíüŒ∏,Œ∏‚ààŒòsubscriptùíüùúÉùúÉŒò\mathcal{D}_{\theta},\,\theta\in\Theta are probability laws on ŒûŒû\Xi. For all 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, we assume that there exists Œ∏1,‚Ä¶,Œ∏N‚ààŒòsubscriptùúÉ1‚Ä¶subscriptùúÉùëÅŒò\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{N}\in\Theta such that ùíüi=ùíüŒ∏isubscriptùíüùëñsubscriptùíüsubscriptùúÉùëñ\mathcal{D}_{i}=\mathcal{D}_{\theta_{i}}, and that the agents are drawn from a probability distribution with density ŒΩùúà\nu on ŒòŒò\Theta: (Œ∏i)isubscriptsubscriptùúÉùëñùëñ(\theta_{i})_{i} is a sequence of i.i.d.¬†vectors sampled from ŒòŒò\Theta with density ŒΩùúà\nu.

This aims at modelling a geometric structure on the agents distributions: agents iùëñi and jùëój such that Œ∏isubscriptùúÉùëñ\theta_{i} and Œ∏jsubscriptùúÉùëó\theta_{j} are nearby in the set ŒòŒò\Theta share similar distributions. We quantify this in the following way: there exists a continuous function b:Œò2‚Üí‚Ñù+:ùëè‚ÜísuperscriptŒò2superscript‚Ñùb:\Theta^{2}\to\mathbb{R}^{+} such that for any (Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚ààŒò2ùúÉsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤superscriptŒò2(\theta,\theta^{\prime})\in\Theta^{2}, d‚Ñã‚Äã(Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤)‚©Ωb‚Äã(Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤)subscriptùëë‚ÑãùúÉsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤ùëèùúÉsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤d_{\mathcal{H}}(\theta,\theta^{\prime})\leqslant b(\theta,\theta^{\prime}). In sensor networks, ŒòŒò\Theta is some domain of ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2} of ‚Ñù3superscript‚Ñù3\mathbb{R}^{3}, each agent is a sensor located at a physical position in ŒòŒò\Theta, whose goal is to predict based on noisy local observations (e.g.¬†temperature, pollution,¬†‚Ä¶) that are space-continuous. More generally, if agents model a population (agent iùëñi being an individual in the population) in some geographical location Œò‚äÇùíÆ2ŒòsubscriptùíÆ2\Theta\subset\mathcal{S}_{2} (sphere in ‚Ñù3superscript‚Ñù3\mathbb{R}^{3}) (ranging from cities, countries, continents, or the whole wide world), and if we are interested in speech-recognition models, a fair assumption is to have similar local distributions for nearby agents. The distribution ŒΩùúà\nu is then the geographical density of agents.

The infinitely-many-agents limit is obtained by taking N‚Üí‚àû‚ÜíùëÅN\to\infty with our geometric structure on the agents: we obtain a continuum of agents parameterized by Œ∏‚ààŒòùúÉŒò\theta\in\Theta, with density ŒΩùúà\nu on ŒòŒò\Theta. For every Œ∏‚ààŒòùúÉŒò\theta\in\Theta, we write:

fŒ∏‚Äã(x)=ùîºŒæ‚àºùíüŒ∏‚Äã[‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)],x‚ààùí≥,formulae-sequencesubscriptùëìùúÉùë•subscriptùîºsimilar-toùúâsubscriptùíüùúÉdelimited-[]‚Ñìùë•ùúâùë•ùí≥f_{\theta}(x)=\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim\mathcal{D}_{\theta}}[\ell(x,\xi)]\,,\quad x\in\mathcal{X}\,,

Appendix B Proof of Lower-Bounds (Theorem¬†1 and Corollary¬†1)

B.1. General framework to prove lower bounds

The idea is that, when optimizing a function f‚Äã(x)=ùîº‚Äã[‚Ñì‚Äã(x,Œæ)]ùëìùë•ùîºdelimited-[]‚Ñìùë•ùúâf(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[\ell(x,\xi)\right] and finding a good approximation of a minimizer x‚ãÜsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜx^{\star}, we learn some information on the distribution ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} over which samples are drawn. In order to prove lower bounds, we construct a loss function ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell, and distributions ùíü1Œ±,‚Ä¶,ùíüNŒ±superscriptsubscriptùíü1ùõº‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùíüùëÅùõº\mathcal{D}_{1}^{\alpha},\ldots,\mathcal{D}_{N}^{\alpha}, where Œ±ùõº\alpha is a random parameter. We argue that minimizing (in the all-for-all or all-for-one settings) the objective function up to a certain precision gives a good estimator (quantified) of the random seeds Œ±ùõº\alpha. Then, using Fano inequality, we bound the efficiency of such an estimator in terms of number of oracle calls, obtaining a lower bound on the sample complexity. This approach is inspired by¬†Agarwal et¬†al. [2012], who prove IT-lower bounds for stochastic gradient descent. We adapt their proof technique to the personalized and multi-agent setting.

Constructing difficult loss functions

For any two functions f,g:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëìùëî‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñùf,g:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, we define the discrepancy measure œÅ‚Äã(f,g)ùúåùëìùëî\rho(f,g) as:

œÅ‚Äã(f,g)=infx‚àà‚Ñùd{f‚Äã(x)+g‚Äã(x)‚àíf‚Äã(xf‚àó)‚àíg‚Äã(xf‚àó)},ùúåùëìùëîsubscriptinfimumùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëùëìùë•ùëîùë•ùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëìùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëì\rho(f,g)=\inf_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\Big{\{}f(x)+g(x)-f(x_{f}^{*})-g(x_{f}^{*})\Big{\}}\,,

which is a pseudo metrics. Now, for a finite set ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V} of parameters, let ùí¢‚Äã(Œ¥)={gŒ±Œ¥,Œ±‚ààùí±}ùí¢ùõøsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùõºùõøùõºùí±\mathcal{G}(\delta)={{\left\{g_{\alpha}^{\delta}\,,\,\alpha\in\mathcal{V}\right\}}} be a set of functions indexed by ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V}, that depend on Œ¥ùõø\delta (fixed in the set). The dependency of each gŒ±‚ààùí¢‚Äã(Œ¥)subscriptùëîùõºùí¢ùõøg_{\alpha}\in\mathcal{G}(\delta) is left implicit in the following subsections. We define:

œà‚Äã(Œ¥)=inff,g‚ààùí¢‚Äã(Œ¥)œÅ‚Äã(f,g).ùúìùõøsubscriptinfimumùëìùëîùí¢ùõøùúåùëìùëî\psi(\delta)=\inf_{f,g\in\mathcal{G}(\delta)}\rho(f,g)\,.

Minimizing is Bernoulli parameters identification

The two following lemmas justify that optimizing a function gŒ±‚ààùí¢‚Äã(Œ¥)subscriptùëîùõºùí¢ùõøg_{\alpha}\in\mathcal{G}(\delta) to a precision of order œà‚Äã(Œ¥)ùúìùõø\psi(\delta) is more difficult than estimating the parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha.

Lemma 1 (Agarwal et¬†al. [2012]).

For any x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, there can be at most one function gŒ±subscriptùëîùõºg_{\alpha} in ùí¢‚Äã(Œ¥)ùí¢ùõø\mathcal{G}(\delta) such that:

gŒ±‚Äã(x)‚àíinf‚ÑùdgŒ±<œà‚Äã(Œ¥)3.subscriptùëîùõºùë•subscriptinfimumsuperscript‚Ñùùëësubscriptùëîùõºùúìùõø3g_{\alpha}(x)-\inf_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}g_{\alpha}<\frac{\psi(\delta)}{3}\,.
Lemma 2 (Agarwal et¬†al. [2012]).

Assume that for some fixed but unknown Œ±‚ààùí±ùõºùí±\alpha\in\mathcal{V} there exists a method ‚Ñ≥Tsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëá\mathcal{M}_{T} based on the data œï={X1,‚Ä¶,XT}italic-œïsubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëá\phi=\{X_{1},...,X_{T}\} that returns xTsuperscriptùë•ùëáx^{T} (function of œïitalic-œï\phi) satisfying an error of:

where the mean is taken over the randomness of both the oracle Œ¶Œ¶\Phi, the method ‚Ñ≥Tsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëá\mathcal{M}_{T} and Œ±‚ààùí±ùõºùí±\alpha\in\mathcal{V} if random. Then, there exists a hypothesis test Œ±^:œï‚Üíùí±:^ùõº‚Üíitalic-œïùí±\hat{\alpha}:\phi\to\mathcal{V} such that:

maxŒ±‚ààùí±‚Å°‚Ñôœï‚Äã(Œ±^‚â†Œ±)‚©Ω13.subscriptùõºùí±subscript‚Ñôitalic-œï^ùõºùõº13\max_{\alpha\in\mathcal{V}}\mathbb{P}_{\phi}\big{(}\hat{\alpha}\neq\alpha\big{)}\leqslant\frac{1}{3}\,.

Suppose now that the parameter Œ±ùõº\alpha in the previous Lemma is chosen uniformly at random in ùí±ùí±\mathcal{V}. Let Œ±^:œï‚Üíùí±:^ùõº‚Üíitalic-œïùí±\hat{\alpha}:\phi\to\mathcal{V} be a hypothesis test estimating Œ±ùõº\alpha. By Fano inequality [Cover and Thomas, 2005], we have:

‚Ñô‚Äã(Œ±^‚â†Œ±)‚©æ1‚àíI‚Äã(œï,Œ±)+ln‚Å°(2)|ùí±|,‚Ñô^ùõºùõº1ùêºitalic-œïùõº2ùí±\mathbb{P}\big{(}\hat{\alpha}\neq\alpha)\geqslant 1-\frac{I\big{(}\phi,\alpha\big{)}+\ln(2)}{|\mathcal{V}|}\,, (9)

where I‚Äã(œï,Œ±)ùêºitalic-œïùõºI\big{(}\phi,\alpha\big{)} is the mutual information between œïitalic-œï\phi and Œ±ùõº\alpha, that we need to upper-bound. Combining Fano inequality with Lemmas¬†1 and¬†2, fixing a target error Œµ=œà‚Äã(Œ¥)ùúÄùúìùõø\varepsilon=\psi(\delta), we obtain a lower bound on the sample complexity TŒµsubscriptùëáùúÄT_{\varepsilon}:

Appendix C All-for-all lower bound

Theorem¬†1 immediately yields a Corollary providing lower bounds for the all-to-all problem:

Corollary 1.

Let Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0, bùëèb verifying the triangle inequality, B>0,r>0formulae-sequenceùêµ0ùëü0B>0,r>0. 1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚©ΩŒµ.1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜùúÄ\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\varepsilon\,.

where TùëáT is the number of stochastic gradients sampled from all agents. Then we have:

T‚©æC‚Äãr2‚ÄãB2N2‚ÄãŒµ2‚Äã‚àëi=1N1ùí©iŒµ‚Äã(b4‚ÄãN).ùëáùê∂superscriptùëü2superscriptùêµ2superscriptùëÅ2superscriptùúÄ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅ1superscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄùëè4ùëÅT\geqslant\frac{Cr^{2}B^{2}}{N^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4N})}\,.

Appendix D All-for-one upper-bounds

We provide the following relaxation of bias assumption¬†B.2, a generalization of classical function dissimilarities assumptions Karimireddy et¬†al. [2020], Chayti et¬†al. [2021] to our setting.

  1. B.3

    For all 1‚©Ωi‚©ΩN1ùëñùëÅ1\leqslant i\leqslant N, for any stochastic vector Œª‚àà‚ÑùNùúÜsuperscript‚ÑùùëÅ\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N} (non-negative entries that sum to 1), and for all x‚àà‚Ñùdùë•superscript‚Ñùùëëx\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where gŒª‚Äã(x)=‚àëj=1NŒªj‚Äã‚àáfj‚Äã(x)subscriptùëîùúÜùë•superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëó‚àásubscriptùëìùëóùë•g_{\lambda}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}\nabla f_{j}(x):

    ‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àígŒª‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2‚©Ωm‚Äã‚ÄñgŒª‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2+‚àëj=1NŒªj‚Äãb~i‚Äãj.superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•subscriptùëîùúÜùë•2ùëösuperscriptnormsubscriptùëîùúÜùë•2superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëósubscript~ùëèùëñùëó{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-g_{\lambda}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant m{{\left\|g_{\lambda}(x)\right\|}}^{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}\tilde{b}_{ij}\,. (13)

In a similar setting (NùëÅN agents with heterogeneous functions), Karimireddy et¬†al. [2020], Deng et¬†al. [2020], Chayti et¬†al. [2021] assume that for a fixed agent (or for any agent) iùëñi, ‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáf¬Ø‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2‚©Ωm‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáf¬Ø‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2+Œ∂2superscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñùë•‚àá¬Øùëìùë•2ùëösuperscriptnorm‚àá¬Øùëìùë•2superscriptùúÅ2{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla\bar{f}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant m{{\left\|\nabla\bar{f}(x)\right\|}}^{2}+\zeta^{2} (or similar assumptions) where f¬Ø¬Øùëì\bar{f} is the mean of all functions. (B.2) is the simplest relaxation of this to the more general setting where all agents want to minimize their local function, while¬†(B.3) is a relaxation that keeps the less-restrictive first term for some m‚©æ0ùëö0m\geqslant 0.

We prove the following intermediate result.

Theorem 6 (WGA).

  1. 6.a

    Use the asynchronous oracle. Assume that for all k‚©æ0ùëò0k\geqslant 0 and iùëñi, ‚Äñxk‚àíxi‚ãÜ‚Äñ‚©ΩDnormsuperscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜùê∑{{\left\|x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant D for some D>0ùê∑0D>0.     ùîº‚Äã[1K‚Äã‚àë0‚©Ωk<KFik]ùîºdelimited-[]1ùêæsubscript0ùëòùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùëñùëò\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{0\leqslant k<K}F_{i}^{k}\right] ‚©Ω2‚ÄãD2‚ÄãB2KN‚Äã‚àëj=1NŒªj2+‚àë1‚©Ωj‚©ΩNŒªj‚Äãbi‚Äãj.absent2superscriptùê∑2superscriptùêµ2ùêæùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëó2subscript1ùëóùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëósubscriptùëèùëñùëó\displaystyle\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2D^{2}B^{2}}{\frac{K}{N}}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}}+\sum_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\lambda_{j}b_{ij}\,.
  2. 6.b

    Use the synchronous oracle. In Theorem¬†6.b upper-bound, the first term is the optimization term, and vanishes exponentially quickly in front of the second and third ones (if they are non null), and is not reminiscent of our personalized problem. The second is the noise term (referred to as the statistical term), while the third is a bias term, making appear as advertised in the introduction a bias-variance trade-off. In Theorem¬†6.a, only the statistical and the bias terms are present. In both cases, a right choice of Œªi‚ÄãjsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó\lambda_{ij} matches the lower bound of Theorem¬†1 in terms of sample complexity, for Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0 small enough such that the optimization term vanishes in front of the statistical one. In Theorem¬†6.a, Dùê∑D plays the role of rùëür in the lower bound (and can be more restrictive). Parameters Œº,Lùúáùêø\mu,L in Theorem¬†6.b can take any value, while they are fixed in our lower bounds (with Œ∫=1ùúÖ1\kappa=1).

Then, under either bias assumption¬†(B.2) or¬†(B.3), we have:

‚©Ω2‚Äã(m‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfŒª‚Äã(xk)‚Äñ2+‚àëj=1NŒªi‚Äãj‚Äãb~i‚Äãj)+2‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfŒª‚Äã(xk)‚Äñ2absent2ùëösuperscriptnorm‚àásuperscriptùëìùúÜsuperscriptùë•ùëò2superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscript~ùëèùëñùëó2superscriptnorm‚àásuperscriptùëìùúÜsuperscriptùë•ùëò2\displaystyle\leqslant 2(m{{\left\|\nabla f^{\lambda}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}\tilde{b}_{ij})+2{{\left\|\nabla f^{\lambda}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2}
‚©Ω2‚Äã‚àëj=1NŒªi‚Äãj‚Äãb~i‚Äãj+4‚ÄãL‚Äã(m+1)‚Äã(fŒª‚Äã(xk)‚àífŒª‚Äã(xŒª)).absent2superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëñùëósubscript~ùëèùëñùëó4ùêøùëö1superscriptùëìùúÜsuperscriptùë•ùëòsuperscriptùëìùúÜsuperscriptùë•ùúÜ\displaystyle\leqslant 2\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}\tilde{b}_{ij}+4L(m+1)(f^{\lambda}(x^{k})-f^{\lambda}(x^{\lambda}))\,.

We conclude using fi‚Äã(xk)‚àífi‚Äã(xi‚ãÜ)‚©Ω12‚ÄãŒº‚Äã‚Äñ‚àáfi‚Äã(xk)‚Äñ2subscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùë•ùëòsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ‚ãÜ12ùúásuperscriptnorm‚àásubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùë•ùëò2f_{i}(x^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{2\mu}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2} and b~i‚Äãj=Œº‚Äãbi‚Äãjsubscript~ùëèùëñùëóùúásubscriptùëèùëñùëó\tilde{b}_{ij}=\mu b_{ij}.

This result is valid under any m‚©æ0ùëö0m\geqslant 0, and gives the first part of Theorem¬†7.2. If m‚©Ω1/2ùëö12m\leqslant 1/2, one can use Theorem 1 in¬†Chayti et¬†al. [2021] with the set of agents jùëój such that bi‚Äãj‚©ΩŒµsubscriptùëèùëñùëóùúÄb_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon, agent 00 is agent iùëñi, with Œ±=1/ùí©iŒµ‚Äã(2‚Äãb)ùõº1superscriptsubscriptùí©ùëñùúÄ2ùëè\alpha=1/\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b), to obtain the sample complexity without the Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa factor.

Appendix E All-for-all upper-bounds

We first begin with the following simple lemma.

E.2. Proof of Theorem¬†3.b

Under noise assumption¬†(N.2) and for the synchronous oracle, we stil have:

The function fŒõsuperscriptùëìŒõf^{\Lambda} is however not necessarily strongly convex. Note also that the spectral radius of WùëäW is 111, since ŒõŒõ\Lambda is stochastic. Instead of using stochastic Bregman gradient descent (e.g.¬†Dragomir et¬†al. E.4. Setting¬†2 under Œº=0ùúá0\mu=0

Theorem 8 (All-for-all, convex case).

Let K>0ùêæ0K>0, Œ∑>0ùúÇ0\eta>0, and WùëäW a symmetric non-negative random matrix of the form W=Œõ‚ÄãŒõ‚ä§ùëäŒõsuperscriptŒõtopW=\Lambda\Lambda^{\top} for some stochastic matrix Œõ=(Œªi‚Äãj)1‚©Ωi,j‚©ΩNŒõsubscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùëóformulae-sequence1ùëñùëóùëÅ\Lambda=(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}. Let (xik)k‚©æ0,1‚©Ωi‚©ΩNsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëòformulae-sequenceùëò01ùëñùëÅ(x_{i}^{k})_{k\geqslant 0,1\leqslant i\leqslant N} be generated with Algorithm¬†1. Assume that bias assumption¬†(B.1) holds for some (bi‚Äãj)subscriptùëèùëñùëó(b_{ij}). Under Setting 2, for Œº=0ùúá0\mu=0 (convex case), if Œ∑=N3/2‚ÄãDœÉ‚Äã‚àëi,jŒªi‚Äãj2‚àßN2‚ÄãLùúÇsuperscriptùëÅ32ùê∑ùúésubscriptùëñùëósuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùëó2ùëÅ2ùêø\eta=\frac{N^{3/2}D}{\sigma\sqrt{\sum_{i,j}\lambda_{ij}^{2}}}\wedge\frac{N}{2L}, where ‚Äñxi0‚àíxiŒõ‚Äñ‚©ΩDnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ0superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñŒõùê∑{{\left\|x_{i}^{0}-x_{i}^{\Lambda}\right\|}}\leqslant D for all iùëñi, we have:

Proof.

F.2. SGD under smoothness and convexity assumptions

Lemma 5 (SGD, convex and smooth).

Let f:ùí≥‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üíùí≥‚Ñùf:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R} convex and LùêøL-smooth. Let (ft,gt)t‚©æ0subscriptsubscriptùëìùë°subscriptùëîùë°ùë°0(f_{t},g_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be first order oracle calls such that for all t‚©æ0ùë°0t\geqslant 0:

‚àÄx‚ààùí≥,{ùîº‚Äã[ft‚Äã(x)]=f‚Äã(x),ùîº‚Äã[gt‚Äã(x)]=‚àáf‚Äã(x),ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñgt‚Äã(x)‚àí‚àáf‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2]‚©ΩœÉ2,\forall x\in\mathcal{X}\,,\quad\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\left[f_{t}(x)\right]=f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}(x)\right]=\nabla f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}(x)-\nabla f(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\sigma^{2}\,,\end{aligned}\right.

for some œÉ>0ùúé0\sigma>0. Let (xt)t‚©æ0subscriptsubscriptùë•ùë°ùë°0(x_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be generated with:

‚àÄt‚©æ0,xt+1=xt‚àíŒ∑‚Äãgt‚Äã(xt),formulae-sequencefor-allùë°0superscriptùë•ùë°1superscriptùë•ùë°ùúÇsubscriptùëîùë°superscriptùë•ùë°\forall t\geqslant 0\,,\quad x^{t+1}=x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})\,,

for a fixed stepsize 12‚ÄãL‚©æŒ∑>012ùêøùúÇ0\frac{1}{2L}\geqslant\eta>0, and assume that all the iterates lie in ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X}. Assume that fùëìf is minimized over ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X} at some interior point x‚ãÜsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜx^{\star}. ùîº‚Äã[f‚Äã(x¬ØT)‚àíf‚Äã(x‚ãÜ)]‚©Ω‚Äñx0‚àíx‚ãÜ‚Äñ2Œ∑‚ÄãT+Œ∑‚ÄãœÉ2.ùîºdelimited-[]ùëìsuperscript¬Øùë•ùëáùëìsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùë•0superscriptùë•‚ãÜ2ùúÇùëáùúÇsuperscriptùúé2\mathbb{E}\left[f(\bar{x}^{T})-f(x^{\star})\right]\leqslant\frac{{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}}{\eta T}+\eta\sigma^{2}\,.

For fixed T>0ùëá0T>0, setting Œ∑=min(1/(2L)),‚Äñx0‚àíx‚ãÜ‚ÄñœÉ‚ÄãT)\eta=\min\Big{(}1/(2L)),\frac{{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}}{\sigma\sqrt{T}}\Big{)} gives:

ùîº‚Äã[f‚Äã(xT)‚àíf‚Äã(x‚ãÜ)]‚©Ω2‚Äã‚Äñx0‚àíx‚ãÜ‚Äñ‚ÄãœÉT+2‚ÄãL‚Äã‚Äñx0‚àíx‚ãÜ‚Äñ2T.ùîºdelimited-[]ùëìsuperscriptùë•ùëáùëìsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜ2normsuperscriptùë•0superscriptùë•‚ãÜùúéùëá2ùêøsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùë•0superscriptùë•‚ãÜ2ùëá\mathbb{E}\left[f(x^{T})-f(x^{\star})\right]\leqslant\frac{2{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}\sigma}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{2L{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}}{T}\,.

Thus, for fixed target precision Œµ>0ùúÄ0\varepsilon>0, we have:

with a number of oracle calls

Proof.

Denote et=ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñxt‚àíx‚ãÜ‚Äñ2]subscriptùëíùë°ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùë•ùë°superscriptùë•‚ãÜ2e_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}\right]. We have:

et+1‚àíetsubscriptùëíùë°1subscriptùëíùë°\displaystyle e_{t+1}-e_{t} ‚©Ω‚àí2‚ÄãŒ∑‚Äã‚ü®‚àáf‚Äã(xt),xt‚àíx‚ãÜ‚ü©+Œ∑2‚Äãùîº‚Äã[‚Äñgt2‚Äñ]absent2ùúÇ‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë•ùë°superscriptùë•ùë°superscriptùë•‚ãÜsuperscriptùúÇ2ùîºdelimited-[]normsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùë°2\displaystyle\leqslant-2\eta\langle\nabla f(x^{t}),x^{t}-x^{\star}\rangle+\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}^{2}\right\|}}\right]
‚©Ω‚àí2‚ÄãŒ∑‚Äãft+Œ∑2‚Äã(ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñ‚àáf‚Äã(xt)‚Äñ2]+œÉ2)absent2ùúÇsubscriptùëìùë°superscriptùúÇ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnorm‚àáùëìsuperscriptùë•ùë°2superscriptùúé2\displaystyle\leqslant-2\eta f_{t}+\eta^{2}(\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}^{2}\right]+\sigma^{2})

where we used convexity and smoothness assumptions. Then, summing:

‚àët<Tft‚©Ωe0‚àíeTŒ∑+T‚ÄãŒ∑‚ÄãœÉ2,subscriptùë°ùëásubscriptùëìùë°subscriptùëí0subscriptùëíùëáùúÇùëáùúÇsuperscriptùúé2\sum_{t<T}f_{t}\leqslant\frac{e_{0}-e_{T}}{\eta}+T\eta\sigma^{2}\,,

leading to the desired result. ‚àé

F.3. SGD under convex assumptions

Lemma 6 (SGD, convex).

Let f:ùí≥‚Üí‚Ñù:ùëì‚Üíùí≥‚Ñùf:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R} convex. Let (ft,gt)t‚©æ0subscriptsubscriptùëìùë°subscriptùëîùë°ùë°0(f_{t},g_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be first order oracle calls such that for all t‚©æ0ùë°0t\geqslant 0:

‚àÄx‚ààùí≥,{ùîº‚Äã[ft‚Äã(x)]=f‚Äã(x),ùîº‚Äã[gt‚Äã(x)]‚àà‚àÇf‚Äã(x),ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñgt‚Äã(x)‚Äñ2]‚©ΩB2,\forall x\in\mathcal{X}\,,\quad\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\left[f_{t}(x)\right]=f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}(x)\right]\in\partial f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant B^{2}\,,\end{aligned}\right.

for some B>0ùêµ0B>0. For pùí≥subscriptùëùùí≥p_{\mathcal{X}} the projection on the convex set ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X}, let (xt)t‚©æ0subscriptsubscriptùë•ùë°ùë°0(x_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be generated with:

‚àÄt‚©æ0,xt+1=pùí≥‚Äã(xt‚àíŒ∑‚Äãgt‚Äã(xt)),formulae-sequencefor-allùë°0superscriptùë•ùë°1subscriptùëùùí≥superscriptùë•ùë°ùúÇsubscriptùëîùë°superscriptùë•ùë°\forall t\geqslant 0\,,\quad x^{t+1}=p_{\mathcal{X}}\left(x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})\right)\,,

for a fixed stepsize Œ∑>0ùúÇ0\eta>0. Assume that fùëìf is minimized over ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X} at some interior point x‚ãÜsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜx^{\star}. We have for any T>0ùëá0T>0 and for Œ∑=2‚ÄãD2B2‚ÄãTùúÇ2superscriptùê∑2superscriptùêµ2ùëá\eta=\sqrt{\frac{2D^{2}}{B^{2}T}} for D2‚©æ‚Äñx0‚àíx‚ãÜ‚Äñ2superscriptùê∑2superscriptnormsuperscriptùë•0superscriptùë•‚ãÜ2D^{2}\geqslant{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}:

f‚Äã(1T‚Äã‚àët<Txt)‚àíf‚Äã(x‚ãÜ)‚©Ω2T‚ÄãB‚ÄãD.ùëì1ùëásubscriptùë°ùëásuperscriptùë•ùë°ùëìsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜ2ùëáùêµùê∑f\left(\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t<T}x^{t}\right)-f(x^{\star})\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2}{T}}BD\,.

Proof.

For any y‚ààùí≥ùë¶ùí≥y\in\mathcal{X}, using properties of pùí≥subscriptùëùùí≥p_{\mathcal{X}}:

‚©Ω‚Äñxt‚àíŒ∑‚Äãgt‚Äã(xt)‚àíy‚Äñ2absentsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùë•ùë°ùúÇsubscriptùëîùë°superscriptùë•ùë°ùë¶2\displaystyle\leqslant{{\left\|x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})-y\right\|}}^{2}
=‚Äñxt‚àíy‚Äñ2+Œ∑2‚Äã‚Äñgt‚Äã(xt)2‚Äñ‚àí2‚ÄãŒ∑‚Äã‚ü®gt‚Äã(xt),xt‚àíy‚ü©.absentsuperscriptnormsuperscriptùë•ùë°ùë¶2superscriptùúÇ2normsubscriptùëîùë°superscriptsuperscriptùë•ùë°22ùúÇsubscriptùëîùë°superscriptùë•ùë°superscriptùë•ùë°ùë¶\displaystyle={{\left\|x^{t}-y\right\|}}^{2}+\eta^{2}{{\left\|g_{t}(x^{t})^{2}\right\|}}-2\eta\langle g_{t}(x^{t}),x^{t}-y\rangle\,.

Taking the mean and y=x‚ãÜùë¶superscriptùë•‚ãÜy=x^{\star}, with et=ùîº‚Äã[‚Äñxt‚àíx‚ãÜ‚Äñ2]subscriptùëíùë°ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptùë•ùë°superscriptùë•‚ãÜ2e_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}\right] and ft=ùîº‚Äã[f‚Äã(xt)‚àíf‚Äã(x‚ãÜ)]subscriptùëìùë°ùîºdelimited-[]ùëìsuperscriptùë•ùë°ùëìsuperscriptùë•‚ãÜf_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[f(x^{t})-f(x^{\star})\right]:
